stem: A 28-year-old medical student develops weakness of finger abduction after suffering a laceration at the wrist. Which finding best confirms an ulnar nerve injury at Guyon's canal?

choices.A: Loss of thumb opposition with thenar wasting
choices.B: Inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the index finger
choices.C: Loss of cutaneous sensation over the lateral dorsum of the hand
choices.D: Hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints of digits 4 and 5 with flexion at the interphalangeal joints

rationale_correct: Clawing of digits 4 and 5 (MCP hyperextension with IP flexion) reflects lumbrical and interosseous weakness specific to distal ulnar nerve lesions at the wrist.

rationale_distractors.A: Thumb opposition loss points to a median nerve lesion affecting the recurrent branch.
rationale_distractors.B: Flexion at the DIP of the index finger depends on the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve.
rationale_distractors.C: Lateral dorsal hand sensation is supplied by the superficial branch of the radial nerve.
rationale_distractors.E: Supination is maintained by the radial nerve (supinator, biceps).
